This is a fascinating question. I think it has long answers at both scientific and philosophical levels. And, I don’t believe we know all of the science behind “understanding”. That said, I think a broad overview might be this. In order to “understand” we need to have incoming information be relatable to prior informational constructs. Some kinds of information are relatable even at a genetic level. For example, a baby knows what it is supposed to do when offered the mother’s breast; or, a baby will cry when it has a problem (knowing that crying will serve a purpose). Alternatively, most information becomes “understandable” as we connect the information to developing intellectual constructs. For example, we learn language by learning what words “mean”. The exact processes whereby incoming information is connected to appropriate neuronal structures in order to be processed as relevant are not known. Put simply, we don’t know how the brain connects the image of a dog to other stored information specifically related to dogs. We also don’t know precisely how the concept of “dog” is stored as a concept, and differentiated from the concepts of other similar creatures. One of the fun things about computers is that as computer programmers develop “artificial intelligence” they will need to address these issues. Certainly the constructs they create will be computer versions rather than human versions, but insights into how this may be done will be of service in both arenas.

If we can use a definition, UNDERSTANDING = FILTER. For example, in order “to know” (scire’), the bottom line about “how much it costs,” we should realize that there is an “amplification,” a lense, from each culture, creed, typology, and so on. A Roman would use numerals, somebody else might use numbers, some an abacus, other’s may count on their fingers, others might use a few of this for that, and still others can simply “look” and they would “know” because the lens they use arrives at the same bottom line as the others, given that they had agreed on the equivalences between their counting systems. Of course, not everyone knows what it means when they dream, as another example. They may need to build (bildung: meaning “scaffolding,” “picture,”), a “filter” to comprehend dream language, or poetry, even what other’s “mean.” A “shortcut” like commoner and technical languages that provide filters. Words make sense because they “point” at something one and others can “nod in agreement” as far as what the words, or mathematical formulas, express and refer. Also, when we investigate political ideology, religious fervor and/or fanaticism, and other group mentality, “context” can be similar or different. Thereby, different modalities thru which we understand can agree that they are referring to the same thing, yet there can be disagreements about how to react. They can both nod in approval, or even be turned against each other because they both understand the same thing. What one understands as “good,” might be “bad” for another.

“Understanding” is a tricky term. My own “understanding” divides learning into two phases, which I think of as “acquiring information” and “integrating it.” For example, you read a history book to gather information about the American revolution — everything from the names of military leaders to battle plans, to weaponry, to the progression of victories and defeats. You know there’s a test coming up, so you memorize as much of the information as you can. Later, you read a book about, say, George Washington. At first, you gather information about him, and then you integrate that information with the information you have about the Revolutionary War. Still later, you integrate it with the development of the American constitutional process for choosing a president. The more links you establish among the information you’ve gathered, the more integrated that information becomes, and the more information you have available to deepen your understanding. It’s entirely possible that there’s no maximum limit to “understanding.” It’s also possible that at some point you’ll encounter information that challenges some of your integration, and you’ll have to re-integrate and modify your understanding. I hope this helps a bit, Jim!

How do we understand depends on what do we want to understand. Is it a situation, some person, a person’s feelings and emotions, someone’s expectations, our role as an observer and a listener, or the past experiences that we want to understand. The most challenging part of this process is to identify aspects and expectations around “understand”. We do have a few tools like asking questions to clarify thoughts and assumptions, analyzing behavioural pattern and doing the right thing after recongnizing the emotional expectations of a person. Asking questions is vital to this process, however, remaining cognizant of perceptions and cultural influences on a person’s life or a situation is equally critical. What I understand is a display of love might not be love at all. Above all, having a genuine interest and determination to understand something or somebody without bringing in one’s own baggage from the past is the most difficult step of this process. We understand with our own experiences, and by making a person feel that we could only imagine what they are trying to tell us.

This question could take quite a few books to answer,so I”ll do something different: Epistemology is the philosophy of knowledge - how we get it. There are four basic approaches: Intuition - No one seems to be able to define this Rationalism -mostly for math, where you have premises that are given and you use logic to deduce true things that follow from the premise Empiricism - science - using controlled experiments only on things that are observable in some way Authoritarianism - believing someone whom you have chosen as an expert - this could be a book, like the Bible - no other evidence of true things here except the opinion of the authority (who could be using another system) The key is that if you are using one system, you will find things to be true that are not true in another system or just can’t be studied - God and science, for one. In any argument both parties have to be using the same system.

We understand a subject by gathering and examining relevant knowledge, and deriving information (usually by way of scientific method) about it, such as can be used to communicate about the particular objects and processes compositing the subject. Knowing how to read and write a language, for example, is the essence of understanding. To read a language is to understand its words and their purpose. To write a language is to understand its conventional rules of use. If there were no science we call Linguistics, how much would our understandings differ; how might our life today be different?

There is no one or simple answer since the English word is ambiguous and the human brain multifaceted and not well-understood. Philosophers talk about formal logic and psychologists informal (cognitive errors like confirmation bias, recency bias and the like). In addition your brain has super-fast subconscious processing as discussed in the book “Thinking Fast and Slow”, which involves emotional salience on top of instant determination of possible outcomes (when you are chased by a lion you don’t have time to stop and reason out possible routes of escape). So it depends what you meant by the question exactly.
